journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part K: Journal of Multi-body Dynamics

title-group.article-title: Flexural vibration analysis of an automobile water pump bearing-rotor system with a modified transfer matrix method

article-meta.aff: 1School of Mechanical and Power Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China
2Jiangsu Rongtianle Machinery Co. Ltd, Changzhou, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Qi An, School of Mechanical and Power Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Room 321, Lab-building No. 17, ECUST, 130 Mei-Long Road, Shanghai 200237, People’s Republic of China. Email: anqi@ecust.edu.cn

abstract.p: The loading, elastic deformation and hydrodynamic film effect at each rolling element–raceway contact of automobile water pump bearing are analyzed. Based on this analysis, the total radial stiffness, angular stiffness and radial damping of the two rolling element rows are modelled. These stiffness and damping are taken into the transfer matrix to evaluate the lateral vibration characteristics of a rotor-automobile water pump bearing system. The natural frequencies, mode shapes and unbalance responses of the system are calculated. The effects of the pulley and fan unbalances on the system response under different spindle speeds are studied. The calculation results show that the unbalance response of the system can be reduced by fixing the pulley and fan with the initial phase difference between their unbalances to be 180°, and by increasing the pulley unbalance appropriately when keeping the fan unbalance constant.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The coaxial automobile water pump bearing is a double-row rolling element bearing with a slender spindle and it is widely used in the water cooling system of automobile engines. The bearing and the components mounted on its spindle form a complicate rotor-bearing system. In this system, various vibrations may be caused by the bearing structure, the manufacturing errors of rotational components and the non-homogeneity of materials.1,2 In practical engineering application, generally, the unbalance response of automobile water pump bearing-rotor system is significant.3 This is due to unsuitable matching of the unbalances of rotational components in the system. The unbalance response would cause undesired vibration and noise and reduce the bearing fatigue life. Therefore, it is necessary to further re-examine the vibration characteristics of automobile water pump bearing-rotor system.

The approaches having been widely used to evaluate the vibration behavior of rotor-bearing systems are the finite element method (FEM) and the transfer matrix method (TMM). The primary advantage of the TMM is that the matrix dimension does not increase with the number of elements. Therefore, the TMM is particularly suitable for analyzing rotor-bearing systems when the system elements are numerous. The TMM was firstly proposed by Prohl4 for vibration analysis of rotor systems. Subsequently, Koenig5 and Guenther and Lovejoy6 considered the effects of damping and stiffness of the fluid film bearing on the lateral vibration characteristics of rotor systems. Lund and Orcutt7 established a continuous-mass transfer matrix but neglected both rotary inertia and gyroscopic effects. Bansal and Kirk8 employed the TMM in modal analysis for calculating the damped natural frequencies and examining the stability of flexible rotors mounted on flexible bearing supports. Chao and Huang9 introduced the modified TMM extended from Prohl TMM and obtained more precise natural frequencies and mode shapes. Gu10 combined the TMM with the direct integration method for dynamic analysis of rotor systems. Lee et al.11 proposed a modified TMM to consider the Timoshenko beam element. Kang et al.12 considered a Rayleigh–Euler beam with the effects of rotary inertia and gyroscopic moments when applied the TMM for vibration analysis of asymmetric linear rotor-bearing systems. The TMM was extended to non-linear rotor systems by Lee et al.13 Zu et al.14 proposed an improved TMM for steady-state analysis of rotor-bearing systems with non-linear bearings which has cubic non-linear spring and linear damping characteristics. Maharathi et al.15 used an extended TMM to analyze steady-state unbalance response of a dual-rotor system with a flexible inter-shaft bearing. Liew et al.16 used TMM for transient analysis of non-symmetric unbalanced flexible rotor-bearing systems with non-linear hydrodynamic journal bearings or deep-groove ball bearings. Liew et al.17,18 developed modified transfer matrices for analyzing coupled lateral and torsional vibrations of symmetric and asymmetric systems respectively. He et al.19 studied the non-linear vibration behavior of elastic beam undergoing large overall motion by using Riccati discrete time transfer matrix method. Wu and Chen20,21 applied a lumped-mass TMM for free vibration analysis of a multi-step Timoshenko beam carrying eccentric lumped masses with rotary inertias. Later, they used continuous-mass TMM for free vibration analysis of a non-uniform beam with various boundary conditions. Tsai and Huang22 derived transfer matrix for shafts coupler with parallel misalignment and analyzed the effects of disk unbalance and shaft misalignment on the response and the critical speeds of the system.

From the previous researches, it can be seen that the TMM is available for dynamic analysis of non-linear rotor-bearing systems, but the transfer matrix deriving for a non-linear system is very complicated. A common simplification technique is to apply the TMM after the non-linear elements in the system are linearized according to some reasonable assumptions. Actually, the load–deformation relationship of rolling element bearing is non-linear. However, the stiffness of rolling element bearing changes significantly with bearing load only when the load is small, yet when the bearing load is large, the bearing stiffness changes slightly with the load. Therefore, if the static loads acting on the two rolling element rows of automobile water pump bearing are heavy, it would be acceptable to assume that the system is linear when the rotor vibrates slightly in the vicinity of its static equilibrium position. In addition, the rotary inertias of the components in the rotor-automobile water pump bearing system are relatively large so that it needs to consider the effects of rotary inertias on the system vibration behavior. Although this effect has been considered by many researchers, the angular stiffness of the bearing is usually neglected. In this article, considering the fluid film thickness and elastic deformation, the contact stiffness and viscous damping at a single rolling element–raceway contact are calculated. According to the stiffness and damping at individual contact, the total radial stiffness, angular stiffness and radial damping of the two rolling element rows of automobile water pump bearing are modelled. After the roller and ball rows of the automobile water pump bearing are linearized with the stiffness and damping at their static equilibrium positions, the total radial stiffness, angular stiffness and damping of each rolling element row and the rotary inertias of each disk are incorporated into the general transfer matrix of the system. With this extended transfer matrix, the natural frequencies, mode shapes and unbalance responses of the rotor-automobile water pump bearing system are evaluated. Particularly, the effects of pulley and fan unbalances and initial phase difference between them on the vibration behavior of the system are analyzed and discussed.

sec.title: Structural system and mechanical analysis
sec.p:
The common structure of a rotor-automobile water pump bearing system is shown in Figure 1. On the spindle of the bearing are connected the pump impeller, driven pulley and cooling fan. The outer ring of the bearing is mounted with an interference fit in the pump shell housing. There are several pairs of strengthening ribs around the OD of the pump shell to obtain a large stiffness. Figure 1.
Rotor-automobile water pump bearing system.

The external loads acting on the spindle of automobile water pump bearing include centrifugal forces caused by eccentric masses of the cooling fan and driven pulley, belt tensions from the driven pulley, axial forces from the pump impeller and the cooling fan and the gravity of each component installed on the bearing spindle. Flexural vibration of the rotor (bearing spindle) that directly supported by the two rows of rolling elements may occur, under the action of centrifugal forces caused by eccentric masses of the components such as cooling fan, driven pulley and so on.

sec.title: Stiffness and damping of two rolling element rows
sec.p:
In order to perform the vibration behavior analysis for the rotor-automobile water pump bearing, it is necessary to calculate the stiffness and damping of two rolling element rows of the bearing. The total stiffness of a rolling element row can be expressed as a function of normal stiffness at each rolling element–raceway contact.23 For a single rolling element–raceway contact, the normal stiffness consists of the elastic contact stiffness and film stiffness. As illustrated in Figure 2, if an elementary radial bearing dFy is generated, an elementary displacement dδy between the inner and outer raceway would be caused along the y direction and the elementary normal contact loads dQnj at each rolling element angular position would occur. Then, the normal elementary relative displacement at any rolling element angular position is (1)dδnj=dδrjcosβj=dδycosψjcosβj where βj is the rolling element–raceway contact angle and ψj is the rolling element azimuth angle. Figure 2.
Radial load distribution and displacement at a rolling element row.
Considering the static equilibrium of the rolling element row, it can be determined that (2)dFy=∑j=1NdQnjcosβjcosψj (for the cylindrical roller row,βj=0)

From equations (1) and (2), the total stiffness along the y direction for a rolling element row is obtained as a function of the normal stiffness between inner and outer raceways at each rolling element angular position (3)Kr ty=dFydδy=∑j=1NdQnjdδnjcos2βjcos2ψj=∑j=1NKn tjcos2βjcos2ψj Similarly, the total angular stiffness about the x axis for a rolling element row is given by (4)Kθtx=dMxdθx=∑j=1NdMrjdθrjcos2ψj=∑j=1NKθjcos2ψj

The total radial damping of a rolling element row can be expressed as a function of rolling element–raceway normal damping at each angular position as well. If an elementary relative velocity along the y direction duy is developed between the inner and outer raceways, the elementary normal relative velocity dun would occur at individual rolling element angular position and the elementary damping force dQfy along the y direction would be caused. Therefore, the damping along the y direction for a single rolling element row can be given by (5)Crty=-dQfyduy=∑j=1N-dQf njdunjcos2ψjcos2βj=∑j=1NCn tjcos2ψjcos2βj where Qf nj is the normal damping force between the inner and outer raceways at any rolling element angular position, and Cn tj is the normal damping at the corresponding position.

The automobile water pump bearing contains two rolling element rows in which one is comprised by cylindrical fully-crowned rollers and the other is comprised by balls. The contact footprint of a ball–raceway contact is point contact. However, the contact footprint of a roller–raceway contact may either be line contact or point contact because the fully crowned rollers are employed. Due to the difference of contact loads, the rolling element–raceway contacts at each angular position may be in different lubrication regimes such as isoviscous rigid (IVR), piezoviscous rigid (PVR) or elastohydrodynamic (EHD). Thus, the fluid film thickness, stiffness and damping at a rolling element–raceway contact should be calculated according to the lubrication regime and the contact type. The dynamic model of a rolling element–raceway contact is illustrated in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Dynamic model of a rolling element–raceway contact.

The normal stiffness of a rolling element–raceway contact is paralleled by the elastic contact stiffness and film stiffness. The total normal stiffness of a rolling element contacting the inner and outer raceways at any angular position may be calculated using (6)Kntj=(Knij-1+Knoj-1)-1=(Kcij-1+Kfij-1+Kcoj-1+Kfoj-1)-1 where i and o denote the inner and outer raceway contacts respectively, Kc and Kf are the elastic contact stiffness and the film stiffness of a rolling element–raceway contact respectively, and Kn is the normal stiffness. The elastic contact stiffness Kc can be calculated according to the load–deformation relationships of the dry point contact or line contact, while the film stiffness Kf can be calculated using the plateau film thickness formulas for point contacts or line contacts. Taking an EHD point contact for example here, referring to the method proposed by Houpert24,25 and applying the plateau film thickness formula given by Hamrock and Dowson,26 the elastic contact stiffness and the film stiffness can be determined as follows respectively (7)Kc=0.669Eℜ0.411RX0.5δc0.5 (8)Kf=3.874×107ERX16.925G7.91U10 ×(1-0.61e-0.73ke)14.925hc-15.925 where ℜ=RY/RX, G=αE, U=(η0(u1+u2))/2ERX, hc is plateau film thickness and ke is the Hertz contact ellipticity. Regarding the contacts in other lubrication regimes, other two different relationships may be used to calculate the elastic contact stiffness and the film stiffness respectively.

The moment-misalignment angle relationship of a roller–raceway dry contact has been given, for example by Johns and Gohar.27 However, this relationship seems to be unsuitable when the fluid film, the roller centrifugal force and the different load–deformation relationships for inner and outer raceway contacts are taken into consideration. The misalignment angle between the roller and one raceway is no longer half of the misalignment angle between two raceways at any angular position. In other words, the elastic angular stiffness would be different and this should be considered to calculate the total angular stiffness. In order to obtain the angular stiffness between the inner and outer raceways, it is necessary to revert to the slice model introduced by Harris28 and detailed by Johns and Gohar.27 For the cylindrical roller being in equilibrium as shown in Figure 4(a), it is assumed that the roller is divided into a number of slices parallel to the radial plane of the roller and an elementary misalignment angle dθ is developed between the inner and outer raceways. Correspondingly, the elementary load per unit roller length is dq and the elementary misaligning moment is dMr. From the deformation compatibility condition, the normal deformation between the inner and outer raceway at any roller slice location can be determined as follows (9)dδnk=dδcik-dhcik+dδcok-dhcok=Ykdθ Thus, the raceway–raceway normal stiffness per unit length at any roller slice location is defined as (10)knstk=dqkdδnk=(kncik-1+knfik-1+kncok-1+knfok-1)-1 where knc is the elastic contact stiffness per unit length of a rolling element–raceway contact, and knf the film stiffness per unit length of a rolling element–raceway contact. Using the load–deformation relationship given by Houpert24,25 for dry contacts and the plateau film thickness formula proposed by Dowson and Toyoda29 for line contacts, it can be determined that (11)knc=0.282Eℜ-0.1 (12)knf=7.198×105ERX11G5.6U6.9hc-11 Figure 4.
Loads and deformations at the rolling element–raceway contacts: (a) roller–raceway contact; (b) ball–raceway contact.
From equations (9) and (10), the raceway–raceway angular stiffness of at any roller location is given by (13)Kθj=dMrjdθj=∑k=1mknstkjYk2dY

As the ball is in equilibrium as shown in Figure 4(b), the raceway–raceway angular stiffness of at any ball location can be obtained by the following equation, in term of the elementary misalignment angle dθ and the elementary misaligning moment dMr between the inner and outer raceways. (14)Kθj=dMrjdθj=Knj(Dm/2-D/2+ri)2sin2βj

The film damping is primarily developed in the inlet region of the contact area. Dareing and Johnson30 have indicated that there is no significant film damping under EHD condition. Mehdigoli et al.31 further showed that fluid film damping is only effective under hydrodynamic conditions (IVR or PVR). The film damping at a rolling element–raceway contact can be determined by integrating the Reynolds equations. Making use of the method introduced by Hagiu and Gafitunu,32 which is derived under the hydrodynamic lubrication conditions, the film damping of a contact in the lightly loaded zones of each rolling element row is given by (15)Cnξ=-dQfξduZ=L6.66η_ aveRX1.5hc1.5 (ξ=i,o) where η_ ave is the mean viscosity calculated by the mean pressure in the lubricant inlet region of the contact and L is the contact length of the Hertz contact zone. For the line contact, L=Le, and for the point contact, L=2a.

At a single rolling element location, considering the radial relative velocity between the rolling element and a raceway to be just a half of that between the inner and outer raceways, the raceway–raceway normal damping at this location is (16)Cn tj=-dQfjdun=-dQf ij+dQfoj2duZ=12(Cn ij+Cn oj)

The component stiffness and damping of a rolling element–raceway contact and the total stiffness and damping of each rolling element row can be obtained after the static internal load distributions of roller row and ball row are determined. These load distributions can be calculated with the method developed by Li,33 which takes the bearing spindle misalignment, hydrodynamic effects and rolling element centrifugal force into consideration.

sec.title: Natural frequencies, mode and unbalance response
sec.p:
As illustrated in Figure 5, The continuous rotor-automobile water pump bearing system is discretized into a multi-degree of freedom system with n rigid disks and n−1 flexible shafts, using the lumped parameter method. The loads acting on individual disk and shaft are shown in Figure 6. The dynamic moments on a shaft element are the inertia moment and gyroscopic moment caused by the disk motion. The dynamic loads on a disk include the inertia force, the elastic restoring force and moment and the damping force of the bearing element. Figure 5.
Discretization of the rotor-automobile water pump bearing system. Figure 6.
Load analysis of a single shaft and disk.

The equations of motion of any disk (particle) in the system can be described by a transfer matrix as follows (17)(yϕMQ)jL=(1l-l22EI-l36EI01-lEI-l22EI001l0001)j-1 ×{(yϕMQ)j-1L+(00ΔMΔQ)j-1} (j=2,3,…,n-1) where (y,ϕ,M,Q)jT denotes the state variables of the disk element and is written as Zj, the square matrix is the field transfer matrix pertaining to the shaft element and is written as Aj, (0,0,ΔM,ΔQ)jT denotes the variation of the state variable between the left and right cross-sections of the disk and is written as ΔZj, and superscripts L and R denote the left cross-section and right cross-section, respectively.

Setting displacement variables y=YCeλt, ϕ=ϕCeλt, then it is assumed that the unknowns are λ=-μ+iωr, pey=0 for free vibration of the system and λ=iωs, pey=Peyeiωst for harmonic forced vibration of the system. Neglecting gyroscopic moments and cross-coupling stiffness of the two rolling element rows, the moment variation ΔMj and the shearing force variation ΔQj are given by (18)ΔMj=-Jxjϕ··j-Kθtxjϕj=(-λ2Jxj-Kθtxj)ϕj (19)ΔQj=mjy··j+Cr tyjy·j+Kr tyjyj+Peyj=(λ2mj+λCr tyj+Kr tyj)yj+peyj where Kr ty and Cr ty respectively denote the stiffness and damping of the two rolling element rows along y direction, Kθtx denotes the angular stiffness of the two rolling element rows about x axis (except that the locations of the two rolling element rows, the stiffness and damping at other locations are zero).

For free vibration of the system, the variations ΔMj and ΔQj on each disk are only related to the disk displacements yj and ϕj. Therefore, the transitive relation between the state variations on the two cross-sections of a disk is described by (20)(yϕMQ)jR =(100001000-λ2Jx-Kθtx10λ2m+λCr ty+Kr ty001)j ×(yϕMQ)jL In equation (20), the square matrix is the point transfer matrix pertaining to the disk element and is written as Bj. This matrix incorporates the radial stiffness, angular stiffness, damping and rotary inertia at the disk location. It is a modified transfer matrix and will improve the calculation accuracy of the system vibration characteristics. The state at one side of the system shown in Figure 5 is transferred to the other side of the system through a global transfer matrix given by (21)ZnR=BnAn-1Bn-1…A1B1Z1L=TZ1L where T is the global transfer matrix of the system. According to the boundary conditions at the boundary points M1L=MnR=0, Q1L=QnR=0, every order natural frequencies ωr and vibration attenuation factors μ of the system can be obtained. The vibration modes of the system are plural modes due to the existing of film viscous damping in the bearing.

Regarding the forced vibration caused by the unbalances, ΔMj and ΔQj at a disk are not only related to the disk displacements yj and ϕj but also include the centrifugal forces caused by the disk unbalance which is independent of disk displacement. The centrifugal force at any disk is given by (22)peyj=mejωs2eiγ0jeiωst where me is the disk unbalance and γ0 is initial azimuth angle of the unbalance.

When the disk centrifugal forces are considered, the transitive relation of state variable between the two sides of the system cannot be expressed by the global transfer matrix such as equation (21) any more. However, if the external excitations are harmonic, the displacements YC1 and ϕC1 would be determined by searching their values in the complex plane to satisfy the boundary conditions MnR=0, QnR=0 at the right end of the system. Thereby the plural amplitudes of unbalance response at each disk (point) could be obtained by equation (17).

sec.title: Calculation example and analysis
sec.p:
WR1530109 automobile water pump bearing is taken as the sample and its corresponding parameters are shown in Table 1, these parameter notations are explained in Figure 1 and ‘Notation’ section. Table 1.
Corresponding parameters of the automobile water pump bearing-rotor system.
D1 (mm) D2 (mm) D3 (mm) DB (mm) DR (mm) Fa _ fan (N) Fa _ impeller (N) Fr _ pulley (N) Jf (T·mm2)
10 15 12 6.35 5 40 260 2000 0.872
Jp (T·mm2) Jv (T·mm2) L1 (mm) L2 (mm) L3 (mm) L4 (mm) Le (mm) mf (T) mp (T)
1.565 0.10 112 16.2 34.0 41.0 7.2 1.5 × 10−3 1.0 × 10−3
mv (T) NB NR PDB (mm) PDR (mm) ri (mm) ro (mm) α (MPa-1) η0 (MPa·s)
0.4 × 10−3 6 9 0.004 0.002 3.26 3.32 0.022 0.2 × 10−6

The radial stiffness, angular stiffness and radial damping of the roller row of automobile water pump bearing determined by the above method are 2.62×105N/mm, 1.10×106N·mm/rad and 18N·s/mm respectively. Similarly, the radial stiffness, angular stiffness and radial damping of the roller row 0.9×105N/mm, 6.93×105N·mm/rad and 14N·s/mm. The stiffness and damping of the two rolling element rows are both increasing with the bearing load increasing. However, under moderate to heavy bearing load, the variation ranges of the stiffness and damping are much smaller than those under light load when the bearing load varies at the same scale. Thus, for the purpose of system linearization, it is supposed that the system vibrates in a small range nearby the static equilibrium position and the stiffness and damping of the two rolling element rows are always equal to those in the static equilibrium. The rotor-automobile water pump bearing system is discretized into 20 disks and 19 shafts. The first three natural frequencies and damping attenuation factors of the flexural vibration of the system are obtained by the TMM and shown in Table 2 the working speeds of automobile water pump bearing are usually between the first critical speed and the second critical speed of the system. Although the vibration modes of the system are plural, they can be described by their real parts attributing to the small damping of the two rolling element rows. The first three mode shapes of the rotor-automobile water pump bearing system are shown in Figure 7. Figure 7.
Mode shapes of the rotor supported by automobile water pump bearing. Table 2.
Natural frequencies and attenuation factors of the system flexural vibration.
Modes Vibration attenuation factors (μ) Natural frequencies (ωr, Hz)
First order 0.31 360.1
Second order 12.54 1983.3
Third order 217.90 3430.5

The manufacturing errors and the non-homogeneity of materials may lead to the eccentric unbalances of the fan, the pulley belt wheel and the pump impeller. These unbalances would affect the vibration behavior of the rotor-automobile water pump bearing system. Figure 8 shows the amplitudes of unbalance responses at the locations of two rolling element rows changing with the bearing spindle speed. The unbalances of the fan, pulley and pump impeller connected with the given automobile water pump bearing are measured by the bearing provider and the data are me f=10g·cm, me p=6g·cm and me v=2g·cm. It can be seen that the amplitudes of unbalance responses at the locations of two rolling element rows increase rapidly when the rotational frequency 2πns/60 of the rotor (bearing spindle) is near to natural frequencies of the system. Namely, the resonances of system occur under this condition. Thus, the working speed of automobile water pump bearing should be far away from the resonance regions to avoid causing oversize amplitudes of flexural vibration of the system. In addition, the amplitude of unbalance response at the ball row location is larger than that at the roller row location under the same rotor speed. However, it is necessary to point out that the above resonant condition is not the only one which can lead to the system resonances. The premature resonance may also take place when the ‘rolling element-pass frequency’ (i.e. no. of rollers or balls × the cage speed) reaches the natural frequency of the system quicker than the actual spindle speed. This premature resonance may be caused by the manufacturing defects (such as off-sized bearing elements, or surface waviness and roughness) and the variable compliance effect. This point has been detailed by Lynagh et al.2 and has been also shown by Wardle34,35 and by Vafaei et al.36 Figure 8.
Amplitudes of unbalance responses at the locations of two rolling element rows under different spindle speeds (a) roller row; (b) ball row.

The unbalance response of the system varies with the unbalance values of the components connected on the bearing spindle and the initial phase angle between them. The influences of the fan unbalance and pulley unbalance on the maximum unbalance response amplitude of the rotor-bearing system are shown in Figure 9. It is obvious that the maximum unbalance response amplitude of the system increases with the fan or pulley unbalance. As the fan is located at the outside end of the cantilever rotor while the pulley is close to the supporting position of the rotor, the influence of the fan unbalance on the maximum response amplitude is more significant than that of the pulley. Within the frequently-used working speed range of the automobile water pump bearing (4000–10,000 r/min), the maximum unbalance response amplitude of the system caused by the fan unbalance decreases with the increase of the spindle speed. However, the maximum amplitude caused by the pulley unbalance firstly decreases, then increases with the increase of spindle speed. Therefore, for this type of rotor-water pump bearing system, the eccentric unbalance of the fan should be reduced as far as possible, and the reasonable rotating speeds should be selected to cur down the unbalance response amplitude of the system. Figure 9.
Maximum unbalance response amplitude under different pulley and fan unbalances at several spindle speeds (a) influence of pulley unbalance; (b) influence of fan unbalance.

Actually, the initial phase difference between the fan and pulley unbalances also affects the system vibration significantly. As shown in Figure 10, the maximum unbalance response amplitude of the system decreases gradually when the initial phase of the fan unbalance is assumed to be constant and the initial phase difference between the pulley and fan unbalances varies from 0° to 180°. The decrease extent of the maximum amplitude depends on the values of the pulley unbalance. As a result, with a given fan unbalance, selecting large pulley unbalance and locating initial phase angle of the pulley unbalance approximately 180° from that of the fan unbalance would effectively decrease the maximum unbalance response amplitude of the rotor-automobile water pump bearing system. Figure 10.
Maximum unbalance response amplitude under various initial phase differences between the fan and pulley unbalances.

list-item.p: The total stiffness and damping of the two rolling element rows of an example automobile water pump bearing are calculated, based on the loading analysis, deformation analysis and lubrication analysis at each rolling element–raceway contact in the bearing. These stiffness and damping are taken into consideration in an improved transfer matrix method to evaluate the vibration behavior of rotor-automobile water pump bearing system. This improved transfer matrix method is appropriate for analyzing the rotor-automobile water pump bearing system under moderate to heavy bearing load, due to the weak non-linearity of load–deformation relationships at the two rolling element rows of the bearing.

The damped natural frequencies, mode shapes of the rotor-automobile water pump bearing system are estimated and analyzed by using the improved transfer matrix method. The calculated vibration frequencies and modes can provide basis for selecting the working speeds for a given automobile water pump bearing or for selecting the type of automobile water pump bearing under a given external load condition.

The influences of the fan and pulley unbalances on the vibration characteristic of the system are investigated. It is found that the maximum unbalance response amplitude of the system increases linearly with the increase of the fan unbalance or the pulley unbalance. The fan unbalance affects the maximum response amplitude much more remarkable than the pulley since the fan is located at the outside end of the cantilever rotor while the pulley is close to the supporting position of the rotor. Hence, in the process of designing, manufacturing and assembling the rotor-automobile water pump bearing, it should pay special attention to the reducing of the fan unbalance.

The investigation about the influences of the initial phase difference between the fan and pulley unbalances on the system vibration shows that the maximum unbalance response amplitude of the system decreases gradually when the initial phase difference between the pulley and fan unbalances varies from 0°to 180°. It is indicated that the maximum unbalance response amplitude of the system can be reduced effectively by matching the fan and pulley unbalances with the initial phase angle between them to be approximately 180°.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

ack.title: Acknowledgement
ack.p: The authors would like to acknowledge the supports and suggestions of Jiangsu Rongtianle Machinery Co., Ltd for this research.
